name: St. John’s Wort
summary: St. John’s Wort (Hypericum perforatum) is a widely used herbal supplement for mild-to-moderate depression, with additional applications for anxiety and sleep disturbances.
description: St. John’s Wort is a flowering plant native to Europe and used for centuries in traditional medicine. Its active compounds, including hypericin and hyperforin, are thought to modulate neurotransmitters such as serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine. It has been shown in multiple clinical trials to be effective for mild-to-moderate depression, sometimes comparable to standard antidepressants. However, its extensive interactions with prescription medications—especially through induction of cytochrome P450 enzymes and P-glycoprotein—make it a high-risk supplement in polypharmacy settings. It is generally well tolerated but requires careful monitoring when combined with other drugs.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for depression treatment)

contraindications: Use with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs, or other serotonergic medications
Concurrent use with immunosuppressants, anticoagulants, or certain chemotherapeutics

items: Adjunctive treatment in seasonal affective disorder
May support mild anxiety and sleep regulation

sections.text: St. John’s Wort is thought to act by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine, while also modulating glutamate and GABA signaling. Hyperforin contributes to neurotransmitter reuptake inhibition, while hypericin may influence melatonin and circadian regulation.

adult.typical: 300 mg standardized extract (0.3% hypericin) three times daily
adult.note: Full antidepressant effects may take 4–6 weeks.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended outside clinical supervision.

sections.text: Antidepressant effects typically appear within 2–4 weeks, with full response by 6–8 weeks.

other: Potent inducer of CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to reduced levels of many medications (e.g., oral contraceptives, warfarin, HIV protease inhibitors, cyclosporine).
Avoid combination with prescription antidepressants due to serotonin syndrome risk.
May increase sensitivity to sunlight; use sunscreen.

items: Drug efficacy if combined with other therapies

sections.lactation: Not recommended; possible infant exposure via breast milk
sections.pediatrics: Not routinely recommended; limited safety data
sections.geriatrics: Caution with polypharmacy due to interaction risk

sections.text: Should be tapered gradually if used for more than several weeks to minimize risk of discontinuation effects (e.g., irritability, sleep disturbance).

items: Efficacy for mild-to-moderate depression is supported by meta-analyses; less effective for severe depression.
Drug–drug interactions are a major clinical concern, limiting safe use in many patients.
Patients should avoid self-medicating if already on prescription psychotropics.
